title: ChIP-seq protocol for sperm cells and embryos to assess environmental impacts and epigenetic inheritance
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Chromatin immunoprecipitation and library preparation on single mouse sperm for H3K4me3
Timing: 5 days
This step describes how to perform a sperm-specific native ChIP-sequencing protocol on the sperm of individual mice for H3K4me3, using 8 million sperm cells, based on Hisano et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]. We highlight our methodologies for mononucleosome isolation post-ChIP, as well as our library preparation procedures.
Antibody preparation (Day 1)
Prepare 0.5% Bovine Serum Albumin (BSA) solution fresh in 1× PBS: 0.25 g of BSA in 50 mL of chilled 1× PBS. Sterile filter and keep solution on ice.
Resuspend Dynabeads Protein A by inverting stock until slurry becomes uniform. Per mouse, pipet 50 μL of Dynabeads for chromatin immunoprecipitation and 50 μL of Dynabeads for pre-clearing into a 1.5 mL tube.
Place Dynabeads on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting Dynabeads.
Remove Dynabeads from magnetic rack and wash with 100 μL of chilled 0.5% BSA solution. Minimize retention of Dynabeads in pipette tip by pipetting slowly.
Place Dynabeads on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting the Dynabeads.
Repeat washing steps d and e twice more for a total of three washes.
After the final wash, resuspend Dynabeads in 80 μL of 0.5% BSA solution for each ChIP tube and 100 μL of 0.5% BSA solution for each pre-clear tube. Distribute 80 μL of the resuspended Dynabeads to 0.2 mL ChIP tubes or 100 μL of resuspended Dynabeads to 0.2 mL input tubes.
Note: Before the chromatin immunoprecipitation, the digested chromatin will be pre-cleared in a Dynabeads Protein A 0.5% BSA solution without any antibody. This step removes molecules from the chromatin solution that bind to the Dynabeads non-specifically.

Add 20 μL H3K4me3 Cell Signaling antibody (Cat#9751) to each ChIP tube (equivalent to 5 μg of antibody per tube).
Place tubes on a rotator at 4°C. Ensure that the tubes undergo the largest possible revolution. Incubate for > 8 h.
Critical: Incubate in 0.2 mL tubes to prevent Dynabeads from drying out on the rim of a 1.5 mL tube.
Alternatives: This protocol can be used to probe other histone marks in sperm. However, it is important to optimize antibody concentration used in order to obtain high signal-to-noise ratios and library complexities (see troubleshooting problems 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]). Optimization can be done by performing the described sperm ChIP-seq experiment using multiple antibody titrations, and subsequently performing low-depth sequencing (approximatively 10 million reads). The amount of antibody to use relies on two factors:
The breadth of the peak in sperm: a broad mark (e.g., H3K9me3) will require more antibody.
The efficiency of the antibody in sperm: this needs to be tested experimentally and may vary by cell type.
Sperm preparation and counting (Day 1)
Critical: Design all ChIP experiments to include each experimental group in every batch. For example, if you have 20 samples and 4 experimental groups (Lismer et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]), perform 5 different ChIP experiments with each batch composed of the 4 experimental groups. Batch effects can occur in sequencing experiments and data should be analyzed to identify the influences experimental day by a principal component clustering analysis. If identified, batch effects can be bioinformatically corrected (Leek et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]) if a balanced experimental design is used (Lismer et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]).
Thaw sperm from different experimental groups on ice.
Add 500 mL of chilled 1× PBS per tube and gently pipette.
Spin tubes at 2,600 × g for 6 min at 4°C.
Confirm the presence of a pellet.

Without disrupting the pellet, remove the supernatant and gently resuspend in 1 mL of chilled 1× PBS.
Repeat washing steps c–e once more.
Ensure that sperm is well resuspended in chilled 1× PBS.
In new tubes, prepare two 1:10 sperm dilutions in ddH2O for each sample: 10 μL sperm and 1× PBS solution and 90 μL ddH2O.
Add 10 μL of diluted sperm to both counting chambers of a Neubauer Improved counting chamber.
Allow sperm to settle in the hemocytometer for 1 min.
Count sperm in the 25 middle squares of the hemocytometer grid (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]H).
Extrapolate the total number of sperm per group in 1 mL of 1× PBS tube: Total sperm # = Average of two sperm counts × dilution factor (10) × 10,000.
Critical: Ensure that sperm tubes are kept on ice during the counting process.
Critical: The sperm counting step will determine the downstream MNase digestion parameters therefore obtaining accurate and reproducible results is fundamental for this experiment. We recommend practicing the counting step beforehand to achieve counting consistency before using actual experimental sperm. If both sperm count replicates vary by more than 10 sperm counts, make two new 1:10 sperm dilutions in ddH2O and count two diluted sperm replicates again (see troubleshooting problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]).
If tubes have over 8 million sperm cells in them, remove enough volume to specifically obtain 8 million sperm cells per tube. Add chilled 1× PBS to obtain a final total volume of 1 mL per tube.

Alternatives: If experimental groups have less than 8 million sperm cells, adjust to obtain uniform sperm numbers across groups, and modify downstream MNase digestion parameters (step 5). We do not recommend using less than 6 million sperm cells as we have never tested it and therefore cannot reliably comment on data quality or read statistics.
Dithiothreitol (DTT) pre-treatment (Day 1)
Critical: Ensure that benchtop centrifuge is at 20°C–25°C.
Prepare 1M DTT solution fresh: 77.13 mg DTT in 500 μL ddH2O.
Add 50 μL of 1M DTT solution to each sample and incubate for 2 h at 20°C–25°C to release the protamines and relax the sperm chromatin before MNase digestion.
5 min before the end of the DTT treatment, prepare a fresh 1M NEM solution: 125.13 mg NEM in 1 mL ddH2O.
Note: NEM is difficult to dissolve. The solution should be incubated at 50°C for 5 min and vortexed.
For each tube, add 120 μL from the upper phase of 1M NEM solution while it is still on the heat block. Pipette up and down 20 times to mix well.
Critical: Do not take the oily bottom phase of the 1M NEM solution. In our hands, doing so will prevent the DTT quenching.
Incubate solution at 20°C–25°C for 30 min to quench the DTT.
Chromatin preparation (Day 1)
Prepare 100 mM DTT solution fresh (for Complete Buffer 1.1): 15.4 g DTT in 1 mL ddH2O.
Prepare Complete Buffer 1.1 Solution using Buffer 1 Stock. For 1 mL:
table:files/protocols_protocol_713_7.csv
Note: 100 μL of Complete Buffer 1.1 Solution per 2 million sperm cells will be required (50 μL of Complete Buffer 1.1 + 50 μL to prepare Complete Buffer Detergent 1.2).
Spin sperm at 2,600 × g for 6 min at 20°C–25°C.

Critical: After the DTT pre-treatment, washes with 1× PBS must be carried at 20°C–25°C and not at 4°C or the sperm pellet will become brittle and not resuspend.
Carefully discard supernatant.
Gently resuspend pellet in 1 mL of 1× PBS.
Spin sperm at 2,000 × g for 5 min at 20°C–25°C.
Carefully discard supernatant.
Gently resuspend sperm pellet in Complete Buffer 1.1 solution using 50 μL of Complete Buffer 1.1 Solution per 2 million sperm cells. For 8 million sperm cells, resuspend in 200 μL Complete Buffer 1.1 solution.
Vigorously pipette up and down 20 times. Ensure that sperm is well resuspended.
Aliquot sperm in 50 μL volumes per tube. For 8 million sperm cells, 4 aliquot tubes will be made per experimental sample.
Make 10% NP-40 stock solution fresh: 100 μL NP-40 + 900 μL ddH2O (for Complete Buffer 1.2).
Note: NP-40 is very viscous and should be pipetted slowly to obtain accurate measurements.
Make 10% sodium deoxycholate (DOC) stock solution fresh: 10 mg DOC in 100 μL ddH2O (for Complete Buffer 1.2).
Prepare Complete Buffer 1.2 Solution: 50 μL of Complete Buffer 1.2 Solution is required per sperm aliquot tube. For 500 μL:
table:files/protocols_protocol_713_8.csv
Critical: Vortex for 1 min to ensure that the NP-40 and DOC are entirely dissolved.
Add 50 μL of Complete Buffer 1.2 solution to each sperm aliquot tube.
Vigorously pipette up and down 20 times.
Incubate on ice for 25 min.
MNase digestion (Day 1)
Critical: Always titrate MNase with every new batch of MNase stock on practice sperm prior to the ChIP experiment to confirm enzyme efficiency. Once MNase is resuspended, make 7 μL aliquots (30 IU/μL) and store in a −20°C freezer. Do not freeze-thaw aliquots.
Prepare MNase Buffer Complete solution. For 1 mL (to process 10 aliquots of 2 million sperm):

table:files/protocols_protocol_713_9.csv
Note: 100 μL of MNase Buffer Complete will be required per 2 milllion sperm cells.
Critical: Always transport MNase on ice and keep MNase Buffer Complete solution on ice. Do not reuse a thawed aliquot.
Add 100 μL of MNase Buffer Complete solution to each tube and mix vigorously by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Incubate at 37°C for exactly 5 min. Use 30 s intervals between experimental tubes or a multichannel pipette to keep MNase digestion time consistent.
Critical: MNase digestion starts when the tube enters the heat block. Absolute consistency in the timing of MNase digestion to ensure consistent mononucleosome digestion across experimental groups and batches. A slight variation in digestion time can lead to batch effects. Uniformity and efficiency of MNase digestion across samples in one batch is verified using an Agilent Bioanalyzer low input DNA chip (step 10.k.)
Stop MNase digestion by adding 2 μL of 0.5 M EDTA. Pipette up and down vigorously. Vortex tubes on maximum setting for 5 s.
Place tubes on ice for 15 min.
Spin tubes at 17,000 × g for 10 min at 20°C–25°C.
Combine supernatants from aliquot tubes from the same mouse sperm. Pipette supernatant carefully to not aspirate debris and protamines present in the pellet. Keep samples on ice. Each experimental group should yield approximatively 800 μL.
Dissolve one tablet of protease inhibitor in 2 mL of ddH2O. Freeze 50 μL aliquots in a −20°C freezer.
Add 50 μL of protease inhibitor cocktail to each 800 μL of pooled supernatants.
Chromatin Dynabeads™ pre-clearing (Day 1)
Note: Pre-clearing digested chromatin removes molecules that non-specifically bind to Dynabeads Protein A, which is aimed to reduce background and increase specificity.
Prepare Combined Buffer solution fresh and place on ice. For 1 mL:
table:files/protocols_protocol_713_10.csv

Note: 500 μL of Combined Buffer solution will be required per experimental sample.
Place Dynabeads from pre-cleared tubes on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting Dynabeads.
Remove Dynabeads from magnetic rack and resuspend in 100 μL of chilled 0.5% BSA solution.
Place Dynabeads on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting the Dynabeads.
Repeat washing steps d and e twice more for a total of three washes.
Resuspend Dynabeads in 50 μL of chilled Combined Buffer solution per tube.
Add pre-clearing Dynabeads resuspended in Combined Buffer solution to sperm chromatin.
Rotate at 4°C for 1.5 h.
Note: If using a new antibody or studying a different histone modification, sequencing the input should not be omitted.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation (Day 1)
After incubation, place Dynabeads from antibody tubes from step 1.h. on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting Dynabeads.
Remove Dynabeads from magnetic rack and resuspend in 100 μL of chilled Combined Buffer.
Place Dynabeads on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting the Dynabeads.
Repeat washing steps d and e twice more for a total of three washes.
Resuspend Dynabeads-Antibody complex in 100 μL of chilled Combined Buffer solution.
Place Dynabeads from pre-clear tubes from step 6.h. on a magnetic rack. To retrieve an input aliquot, remove 10 μL of solution and place in an input tube. Store input tubes a −80°C freezer.
Carefully transfer the remaining pre-cleared chromatin to Dynabeads-Antibody complex tubes.
Place the tubes on a rotator at 4°C. Ensure that the tubes undergo the largest revolution possible. Incubate 12–14 h.
Washing Dynabeads-Antibody complex (Day 2)
Critical: Keep samples on ice as much as possible throughout the washes.
Prepare Wash Buffer A fresh. Autoclave the buffer and chill in a 4°C fridge before beginning the washes. For 10 mL:

table:files/protocols_protocol_713_11.csv
Prepare Wash Buffer B fresh. Autoclave the buffer and chill in a 4°C fridge before beginning the washes. For 10 mL:
table:files/protocols_protocol_713_12.csv
Spin ChIP tubes at 400 × g for 1 min at 4°C.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Remove tubes from magnetic rack and resuspend beads in 1 mL of chilled Wash Buffer A.
Incubate tubes at 4°C for 5 min on a rotator.
Spin tubes at 400 × g for 1 min at 4°C.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Remove tubes from magnetic rack and resuspend beads in 1 mL of Wash Buffer B.
Incubate tubes at 4°C for 5 min on a rotator.
Repeat washing steps e and f with chilled Wash Buffer B once more.
Remove tubes from magnetic rack and resuspend beads in 1 mL of Wash Buffer B. Transfer mixtures to Eppendorf DNA LoBind tubes.
Incubate on a rotator for 5 min at 4°C.
Spin tubes at 400 × g for 1 min at 4°C.
Place tubes on magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Elution (Day 2)
Note: Prepare ChIP Elution buffer during incubations of step 8.
Prepare 1M DTT solution fresh: 77.13 mg DTT in 500 μL ddH2O.
Prepare 1M NaHCO3 solution fresh: 84.01 mg NaHCO3 in 1 mL ddH2O
Prepare ChIP Elution Buffer solution fresh. For 2 mL:
table:files/protocols_protocol_713_13.csv
Heat ChIP Elution Buffer solution to 65°C. Maintaining the elution buffer at this temperature will increase elution efficiency.
For the ChIP tubes, add 125 μL of warmed ChIP Elution Buffer solution to washed Dynabeads-Antibody complex. Mix well by pipetting up and down 20 times. Vortex on maximum setting for 10 s and perform a quick spin.

For the input tubes, add 250 μL ChIP Elution Buffer solution to the tubes. Mix well by pipetting up and down 20 times. Vortex on maximum setting for 10 s and perform a quick spin.
Heat tubes at 65°C for 10 min with 400 × g shaking. For the ChIP tubes, vortex on maximum setting for 5 s every 4 min to resuspend nucleosomes. Perform a quick spin after every vortex.
Note: There are no Dynabeads in the input tubes therefore the tubes can be left on the heat block for the full duration of the two ChIP elutions.
After elution, spin tubes at 400 × g for 1 min at 20°C–25°C and place on a magnetic rack.
Transfer ChIP elution products to new Eppendorf DNA LoBind tubes.
Repeat elution step for ChIP tubes e,g.–i and combine second elution products with appropriate Eppendorf DNA LoBind tubes.
Add 5 μL of 10 mg/mL RNase to all tubes (input and ChIP tubes) and incubate for 30 min at 37°C with 400 × g shaking.
Add 5 μL of 10 mg/mL Proteinase K to all tubes (input and ChIP tubes) and incubate 12–14 h at 55°C with 400 × g shaking.
DNA cleanup and concentration (Day 3) DNA cleanup and concentration can be performed using the Zymo Research ChIP DNA Clean and Concentrator Kit (https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_d5201_d5205_chip_dna_clean_concentrator_kit.pdf[href=https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_d5201_d5205_chip_dna_clean_concentrator_kit.pdf]) with slight modifications:
Note: Perform this step for the input and ChIP tubes if sequencing an input.
In a 1.5 mL tube, add 1,250 μL of ChIP DNA Binding Buffer to each tube (5 volumes per each volume of sample).
Transfer mixture to Zymo-Spin Column in a Collection Tube.

Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s and discard flow-through. Steps c and d will need to be repeated because the volume in each tube exceeds the Zymo-Spin Column capacity.
Add 200 μL Wash Buffer to the column. Rotate pipette around interior of tube to wash walls of the Collection Tubes.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s and discard flow-through.
Transfer columns to new 1.5 mL tubes and add 15 μL of warmed Elution Buffer directly to the column matrix. Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 1 min.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 1 min to elute DNA.
For the same tube, add 15 μL of warmed Elution Buffer directly to the column matrix for a second elution. Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 1 min.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 1 min to elute DNA a second time.
Assess and quantify immunoprecipitation product on an Agilent Bioanalyzer low input DNA chip.
Pause Point: Eluted samples can be stored in a −80°C freezer for up to 1 year before mononucleosome isolation.
Immunoprecipitated mononucleosome isolation (Day 4)
Note: Perform this step for the input and ChIP tubes if sequencing an input.
Critical: Removing non-mononucleosomal DNA fragments ensures specific amplification of mononucleosome fragments during library preparation. Determine cleaning parameters for each sample based on Bioanalyzer electropherogram reports. See https://www.broadinstitute.org/genome-sequencing/broadillumina-genome-analyzer-boot-camp[href=https://www.broadinstitute.org/genome-sequencing/broadillumina-genome-analyzer-boot-camp] for a thorough explanation on how varying Ampure XP Beads volume to solution volume ratio selects for different sizes of DNA. Isolate mononucleosomes as follows:
If samples do not have any high or low molecular weight DNA (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A): perform a non-stringent negative selection followed by a positive selection before library preparation.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/713-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Sperm ChIP-seq Bioanalyzer expected outcomes and mononucleosome isolation

(A) Gold-standard H3K4me3 ChIP Bioanalyzer electropherogram on 8 million mouse sperm from a single male. Perform a low-stringent mononucleosome isolation (0.55× negative selection, 1× positive selection) before library preparation.
(B) Gold-standard H3K4me3 ChIP library Bioanalyzer electropherogram on 8 million mouse sperm from a single male following 10 amplification cycles during library preparation.
(C) Example of an H3K4me3 ChIP Bioanalyzer electropherogram on million mouse sperm from a single male with low (green box) and high (orange box) molecular weight DNA that should be removed before library preparation.
(D) Bioanalyzer electropherogram from (C) after removal of high molecular weight (following a 0.85× negative size selection and 1× positive size selection).
(E) Bioanalyzer electropherogram from (D) after removal of low molecular weight (following a 1.6× positive size selection).
Resuspend Ampure XP beads by inverting stock solution until slurry becomes uniform.
Warm Qiagen Elution Buffer to 65°C.
Adjust sample volume to 50 μL with Qiagen Elution Buffer.
Add 27.5 μL Ampure XP beads to each sample (0.55×) and mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 5 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait for Ampure XP beads to pellet.
Gently retrieve the 77.5 μL of supernatant (negative selection) and place supernatant in a new tube.
Add 50 μL of Ampure XP beads per sample (1×) and mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 10 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait for Ampure XP beads to pellet.
Remove supernatant without disrupting beads.
Wash beads twice with 200 μL of freshly prepared 80% ethanol.
Air dry beads. Beads are dry when they are no longer glossy and when no liquid is visible in the tube.

Elute DNA in 25 μL of warmed Elution Buffer and vortex on high setting for 10 s.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 10 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait for Ampure XP beads to pellet.
Gently retrieve 25 μL of eluted DNA and place in a new tube.
Assess and quantify cleaned product on an Agilent Bioanalyzer low-input DNA chip.
If samples have high molecular weight (di- or trinucleosomes due to inefficient MNase digestion) (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C and 3D) (see troubleshooting problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]): perform a stringent negative selection followed by a positive selection before library preparation.
Resuspend Ampure XP beads by inverting stock solution until slurry becomes uniform.
Warm Qiagen Elution Buffer to 65°C.
Adjust sample volume to 50 μL with Qiagen Elution Buffer.
Add 42.5 μL Ampure XP beads to each sample (0.85×) and mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 5 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait for Ampure XP beads to pellet.
Gently retrieve the 92.5 μL of supernatant (negative selection) and place supernatant in a new tube.
Add 50 μL of Ampure XP beads per sample (1×) and mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 10 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait for Ampure XP beads to pellet.
Remove supernatant without disrupting beads.
Wash beads twice with 200 μL of freshly prepared 80% ethanol.
Air dry beads. Beads are dry when they are no longer glossy and no liquid is visible in the tube.
Elute DNA in 25 μL of warmed Elution Buffer and vortex on high setting for 10 s.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 10 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait for Ampure XP beads to pellet.

Gently retrieve 25 μL of eluted DNA and place in a new tube.
Assess and quantify cleaned product on an Agilent Bioanalyzer low-input DNA chip.
If samples have low molecular weight (overdigestion, short DNA fragments) (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D and 3E) (see troubleshooting problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]): perform a stringent positive selection before library preparation.
Resuspend Ampure XP beads by inverting stock solution until slurry becomes uniform.
Warm Qiagen Elution Buffer to 65°C.
Adjust sample volume to 50 μL with Qiagen Elution Buffer.
Add 80 μL Ampure XP beads to each sample (1.6×) and mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 10 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait for Ampure XP beads to pellet.
Remove supernatant without disrupting beads.
Wash beads twice with 200 μL of freshly prepared 80% ethanol.
Air dry beads. Beads are dry when they are no longer glossy and no liquid is visible in the tube.
Elute DNA in 25 μL of warmed Elution Buffer and vortex on high setting for 10 s.
Incubate at 20°C–25°C for 10 min.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and wait until all Ampure XP beads have pelleted.
Gently retrieve 25 μL of eluted DNA and place in a new tube.
Assess and quantify cleaned product on an Agilent Bioanalyzer low input DNA chip.
Critical: When performing the Ampure XP bead 80% ethanol washes, leave tubes on magnetic stand. Do not resuspend beads in 80% ethanol.
Critical: When drying out the Ampure XP beads, ensure that the beads do not over-dry and crack. This will lead to loss of DNA.
Note: If samples have both high and low molecular weights, we recommend performing the 0.85× negative selection, 1× positive selection first, followed by the 1.6× positive selection.

Pause Point: Cleaned samples can be stored in the −80°C freezer for up to 1 year before library preparation.
Library preparation (Day 5)
Note: Perform this step for the input and ChIP tubes if sequencing an input.
Prepare libraries using the Qiagen UltraLow Input Library Kit using the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=e1e88a40-bf6b-431a-9697-799e14103467&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=e1e88a40-bf6b-431a-9697-799e14103467&lang=en]). For 8 million sperm cells, we use a 1:10 dilution for adapters (step 4) and perform 10 PCR library amplification cycles (step 21) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B). Adapter dilution and PCR cycle number can vary depending on input quantity (see user manual).
Critical: Before beginning library preparation, adjust all samples to obtain the same DNA concentration in each tube.
Critical: Minimizing the number of PCR amplification cycles is important to reduce PCR duplicates. Verify with your sequencing platform the minimum and maximum concentration of DNA required for sequencing. Perform enough PCR amplification cycles to have a final DNA concentration just above the minimum DNA concentration required for sequencing.
Ultra-low-input ChIP-sequencing on 8-cell pre-implantation embryos and library preparation
Timing: 3 days
Alternatives: The steps of the ULI-ChIP-seq described below are specifically optimized for 250 pre-implantation embryo cells (equivalent to 32 × 8-cell embryos) targeting H3K4me3 (Diagenode, Cat#C15410003). The original ULI-ChIP-seq protocol from Brind’Amour et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2], describes in detail the parameters to use if working with 1,000 to 1 million cells. These parameter differences include MNase digestion time and incubation temperature, amount of antibody needed per reaction, and number of PCR amplification cycles used during library preparation. Depending on cell type, cell number, and antibody used, optimization may be required.
Antibody preparation (Day 1)
Dissolve one tablet of protease inhibitor in 2 mL of ddH2O. Freeze 50 μL aliquots in a −20°C freezer.
Prepare Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer fresh and place on ice. For 3 mL:
table:files/protocols_protocol_713_14.csv

Resuspend Dynabeads Protein A and Protein G by inverting stocks until slurries become uniform. For each sample, add 5 μL of Dynabeads Protein A and 5 μL of Dynabeads Protein G in 0.2 mL tubes. Half of the Dynabeads mixture will be used for the pre-clearing step and half will be used for the immunoprecipitation step.
Note: The combination of Dynabeads Protein A and Protein G increases removal of non-specific binding than the use of Dynabeads Protein G alone. Because the Dynabeads are in excess, using both Protein A and Protein G Dynabeads does not hinder the immunoprecipitation.
Place Dynabeads on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting Dynabeads.
Remove Dynabeads from magnetic rack and wash with 200 μL of chilled Complete Immunoprecipitation Buffer. Minimize retention of Dynabeads in pipette tip by pipetting slowly.
Place Dynabeads on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting the Dynabeads.
Repeat washing steps d and e once more.
Remove Dynabeads from magnetic rack and perform a third wash with 200 μL of chilled Complete Immunoprecipitation Buffer.
Ensure that the Dynabeads are well resuspended in Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer. Transfer 100 μL of Dynabeads and Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer to a new 0.2 mL tube. The first tube will be used for the immunoprecipitation step and the second tube will be used for the pre-clearing step.
Place Dynabeads on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting the Dynabeads.
Add 100 μL Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer to the pre-clear tube and 99 μL Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer to the immunoprecipitation tube.
Dilute Diagenode H3K4me3 antibody (Cat#C15410003; concentration 1.4 μg/μL): 1 μL antibody in 13 μL Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer. Mix well by pipetting up and down 20 times.

Note: Each ULI-ChIP tube will use 0.125 μg of H3K4me3 antibody. This amount of H3K4me3 antibody to use has been optimized in Hanna et al. (2018)[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5] for 250 cells.
Alternatives: As for the sperm ChIP-seq, this protocol can be used to probe other histone marks in pre-implantation embryos. Again, it is important to optimize antibody concentration used in order to obtain high signal-to-noise ratios and library complexities (see troubleshooting problems 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]).
Add 1.25 μL of diluted antibody to each immunoprecipitation tube and mix well.
Place tubes on a rotator at 4°C. Ensure that the tubes undergo the largest possible revolution. Incubate for > 8 h.
Critical: Incubate in 0.2 mL tubes to prevent Dynabeads from drying out on the rim of a 1.5 mL tube.
Sample pooling (Day 1)
Note: To obtain enough starting material (approximatively 250 cells), samples will most likely have to be pooled from different tubes of frozen embryos belonging to the same experimental group.
Thaw embryo tubes on ice.
Add 20 μL of nuclear isolation buffer to the first tube and mix by swerving the pipette tip in the tube.
Gently transfer the resuspended solution from the first tube to the second tube that belongs to the same experimental group.
Add 20 μL of nuclear isolation buffer to the second tube and mix by swerving the pipette tip in the tube.
Repeat steps c and d for as many tubes needing to be pooled.
Once pooling is complete, pulse spin tubes at 13,000 × g for 10 s.
Circle on the tube with a thin black marker where the embryos are expected to be pelleted based on the position of the tube in the centrifuge.

Using a tube with 10 μL of ddH2O as a reference, carefully remove enough solution in pooled tube to obtain a final volume of approximatively 10 μL. Pipette slowly and away from the expected pellet to not aspirate the embryos.
MNase digestion (Day 1)
Prepare the following solutions fresh:
10% sodium deoxycholate (DOC): 10 mg DOC in 100 μL ddH2O
200 mM DTT: 30.8 mg DTT in 1 mL ddH2O
50% PEG 6000: 50 mg PEG 6000 in 100 μL ddH2O
1% Triton / 1% DOC: 100 μL 10× Triton + 100 μL 10% DOC in 800 μL ddH2O
After samples have been pooled, add 1 μL of 1% Triton / 1% DOC detergent solution to each tube.
Mix vigorously by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Place tubes back on ice.
Prepare MNase master mix on ice. One sample requires 40 μL of MNase master mix:

Note: The MNase used in the ULI-ChIP-seq procedure is from NEB whereas the MNase used in the sperm ChIP-seq procedure is from Roche (see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]). The 10× MNase Digestion buffer is supplied when purchasing NEB MNase enzyme.
Critical: always transport MNase on ice block and only add to master mix when ready to proceed. Keep master mix on ice.
Mix master mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down 20 times, and lightly vortexing. Perform a quick spin down.
Add 40 μL of MNase master mix to each tube and mix vigorously by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Incubate at 21°C for exactly 7.5 min. Use 30 s intervals between experimental tubes or a multichannel pipette to keep MNase digestion time consistent.

Stop MNase digestion by adding 5.5 μL of 100 mM EDTA to each tube of embryos at designated intervals. Pipette up and down vigorously. Vortex tubes on maximum setting for 5 s.
Add 4 μL of 1% Triton / 1% DOC detergent to each tube.
Place tubes on ice for 30 min.
Digested chromatin manipulation (Day 1)
After incubation on ice, vortex tubes on the medium setting of a vortexer for 30 s.
Add 181.5 μL of chilled Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer per tube (total volume should be 242 μL and digested chromatin should take < 25% of the immunoprecipitated volume).
Place tubes on a rotator at 4°C. Ensure that the tubes undergo the largest possible revolution. Incubate for 1 h.
After incubation, vortex tubes on the medium setting of a vortexer for 30 s.
Chromatin Dynabeads pre-clearing (Day 1)
Critical: For the following steps (steps 5–9), do not mix by pipetting up and down unless otherwise indicated. Doing so may result in losing sample getting in the pipette tip. Mix by flicking tubes.
Place Dynabeads from pre-cleared tubes on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting Dynabeads.
Remove tubes from magnetic rack and add digested chromatin to pre-clear tubes.
Mix by flicking tubes 20 times and perform a quick spin down.
Rotate at 4°C for 1 h.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation (Day 1)
After incubation, place Dynabeads from antibody tubes on a magnetic rack and slowly remove liquid without disrupting Dynabeads.
Pellet Dynabeads from pre-clear tubes. Remove 24 μL of solution from each tube (approximatively 10% of the total volume) and place in an input tube. Store input tubes in a −80°C freezer.
Carefully transfer the remaining pre-cleared chromatin to the Dynabeads:antibody complex tubes.

Place the tubes on a rotator at 4°C. Ensure that the tubes undergo the largest revolution possible. Incubate for 14–16 h.
Washing Dynabeads-Antibody complex (Day 2)
Critical: Ensure Low Salt and High Salt Wash buffers are made fresh and chilled before use. Keep samples on ice as much as possible.
Prepare Low Salt Wash Buffer fresh, sterile filter using a 0.22 μm filter, and place on ice. For 50 mL:

After incubation, place tubes on a magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Remove tubes from magnetic rack and add 200 μL of chilled Complete Immunoprecipitation buffer to each tube.
Mix by flicking tubes 20 times and perform a quick second spin down.
Place tubes on magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Remove tubes from magnetic rack and add 200 μL of chilled Low Salt Wash buffer to each tube.
Mix by flicking tubes 20 times and perform a quick spin down.
Place tubes on magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Remove tubes from magnetic rack and add 200 μL of chilled High Salt Wash buffer to each tube.
Mix by flicking tubes 20 times and perform a quick spin down.
Place tubes on magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Repeat washing steps i and j with chilled High Salt Wash buffer once more and transfer mixtures to Eppendorf DNA LoBind tubes.
Place tubes on magnetic rack and carefully discard supernatant.
Elution (Day 2)
Add 30 μL ChIP Elution buffer to washed Dynabeads-Antibody complex. Mix well by flicking tubes 20 times. Vortex on maximum setting for 10 s and perform a quick spin.

Heat tubes at 65°C for 1.5 h with 400 × g shaking. Vortex on maximum setting for 5 s every 15 min to resuspend nucleosomes. Perform a quick spin after every vortex.
DNA purification (Day 2)
Thaw input tubes from step 18.b. on ice and add 176 μL of Qiagen Elution Buffer to each tube.
Place ChIP tubes from step 20 on a magnetic rack and carefully transfer the supernatant (i.e: the eluted chromatin) to a new tube.
To maximize eluted chromatin retrieval, remove ChIP tubes from magnetic rack and add 170 μL Qiagen Elution Buffer to each tube. Vortex tubes on maximum setting for 30 s.
Place tubes on a magnetic rack and carefully transfer the supernatant to the corresponding eluted chromatin tube.
Add 1 μL of of 10 mg/mL RNase A and incubate for 30 min at 37°C.
Add 1 μL of of 10 mg/mL Proteinase K and incubate for 1 h at 55°C.
During incubation, prepare 3M sodium acetate: 246 mg in 1 mL ddH2O.
Pre-spin phase lock tubes (Qiagen MaXtract High Density, see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) at 13,000 × g for 30 s at 20°C–25°C.
Add input and immunoprecipitated solutions to separate phase lock tubes.
Add 200 μL phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol 25:24:1 to each sample. Mix by inverting tubes 20 tubes and vortex on medium setting for 5 s.
Spin tubes at 13,000 × g for 5 min at 20°C–25°C.
Take out upper phase and place in a new tube while ensuring to not touch gel with the tip of the pipette.
Wash upper phase with 200 μL chloroform to remove any traces of phenol and mix by inverting tubes 20 times.
Spin tubes at 13,000 × g for 5 min at 20°C–25°C.

During the spin, prepare tubes with 20 μL of 3M sodium acetate + 1 μL GenElute Linear Polyacrylamide (LPA).
Note: GenElute LPA is an efficient neutral carrier that is used with ethanol to enhance the precipitation of picrogram quantities of DNA.
Remove supernatant without taking the bottom layer and transfer to the tubes prepared in step n.
Critical: Excess salt at the interphase from the ChIP sample might be visible. Remove the upper phase slowly to not disrupt the salts. After the chloroform wash, it is critical to not contaminate the pipette tip with salts or with the bottom phase of the mixture as this will compromise the elution step. Leaving out a small volume of the upper phase to avoid this is recommended.
Mix well by flicking tubes 20 times.
Add 550 μL of chilled pure ethanol and invert tubes 20 times.
Allow DNA to precipitate for 3 h at −20°C.
After precipitation, spin down DNA at 13,000 × g for 30 min at 20°C–25°C.
Take out supernatant and promptly squirt 200 μL of freshly prepared 70% ethanol onto the pellet so that it detaches from the surfaces of the tube wall.
Remove the 70% ethanol without disrupting or dissociating the pellet. Use a 10 μL pipette when most of the 70% ethanol is removed to eliminate any remnant drops in the tube.
Allow pellet to dry at 20°C–25°C. Pellet is dry when it is fully transparent.
Critical: Ensure that the pellet does not over-dry or it will not dissolve properly in Qiagen Elution buffer. Mark where the pellet is located with a marker outside the tube wall to be able to locate it better when it becomes transparent.

Add 30 μL Qiagen Elution buffer to pellet and let sit for 3 min at 20°C–25°C to rehydrate the pellet. Resuspend the pellet by light vortexing and by pipetting up and down 20 times.
Note: Due to the low amount of starting material, the entire ULI-ChIP experiment is performed blind (i.e., no pellets will be visible). Pipetting with care is critical.
Critical: Move directly to library preparation and do not freeze samples after ULI-ChIP elution. Freezing samples will cause significant loss of material.
Library preparation (Day 3)
Prepare libraries using the Qiagen UltraLow Input Library Kit using the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=e1e88a40-bf6b-431a-9697-799e14103467&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=e1e88a40-bf6b-431a-9697-799e14103467&lang=en]). For approximatively 250 cells (equivalent to 30–32 × 8-cell embryos), we use a 1:1000 dilution for adapters (step 4) and perform 18 PCR library amplification cycles (step 21) (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A–4C).

Low-input mRNA-seq on pre-implantation embryos
Timing: 2–3 days
This step describes how to isolate total RNA on approximatively 100 pre-implantation 8-cell embryo cells and build messenger RNA libraries for mRNA-Seq.

Critical: RNA degrades rapidly and obtaining high quality RNA with a RIN > 8 is necessary for mRNA-Seq because the first step for library preparation relies on a poly(A) tail selection (see troubleshooting problems 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5]).
Total RNA extraction (Day 1)
Note: The use of column-based methods for low-input extractions is not recommended because they lead to increased RNA loss.
Critical: Volume in tubes with embryo cells should comprise less than 10% of total Tri-Reagent volume.
Thaw tubes with embryo cells in DNA/RNA Protection Reagent on ice and pool embryos if necessary. In Lismer et al., we only pooled embryos that were sired by the same males.
Add 750 μL of Tri-Reagent. Mix up and down 10 times with a pipette to completely lyse cells.
Leave at 20°C–25°C for 5 min.
Add 150 μL of chloroform.
Vortex thoroughly on medium setting for 15 s.
Spin tubes at 13,000 × g and 4°C for 15 min.
Remove the top aqueous phase while leaving some behind to avoid contamination by interphase (DNA) and organic phase (protein, lipids). Ensure that pipette tip does not come into contact with these bottom phases.
Add 1 μL of GenElute Linear Polyacrylamide (LPA) to retrieved aqueous phases and mix vigorously by inverting the tubes 10 times and pulse vortexing.
Precipitate the RNA using 500 μL of ice-cold isopropanol. Precipitate in a −20°C freezer for 2.5 h.
Spin tubes at 13,000 × g and 4°C for 30 min.
Rapidly remove and discard liquid.
Wash pellet with freshly prepared 70% ethanol. Circle with a thin marker the location of the pellet on the tube because the pellet becomes transparent after it dries.
Once the pellet is translucent and liquid is no longer visible in the tube, resuspend the pellet in 12 μL of ddH2O.

Verify total RNA integrity and quantify using the Agilent RNA 6000 Pico Kit (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).

Critical: Move directly to library preparation and do not freeze samples after total RNA extraction. Freezing samples will cause significant loss of material due to RNA degradation.
Library preparation (Day 2–3)
For library preparation, use NEBNext Single Cell/Low Input RNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina following manufacturer’s instructions in “Protocol for Low Input RNA” for input < 5 ng total RNA per reaction (https://international.neb.com/protocols/2018/04/25/protocol-for-low-input-rna-cdna-synthesis-amplification-and-library-generation[href=https://international.neb.com/protocols/2018/04/25/protocol-for-low-input-rna-cdna-synthesis-amplification-and-library-generation]). For approximatively 100 cells (equivalent to 12–14 × 8-cell embryos), we perform 15 amplification cycles at the cDNA Amplification Step (step 2.4) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B) and 8 amplification cycles for the PCR Enrichment Step (step 2.10) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C).
Critical: In Section 2.2, use 11 μl of total RNA per sample and remove ddH2O from Section 2.3 (Reverse Transcription and Template Switching).
Note: In Lismer et al., DNase treatment was not used for 100 cells because it led to too much material loss. The poly(A) tail selection was sufficient to generate clean mRNA libraries that did not contain genomic DNA contamination.
Pause Point: We do not recommend pausing and freezing mRNA or cDNA until completion of the cDNA amplification by PCR (Section 2.4).
